title: How to start an argumentative writing - Quora

response.answer_text: Short version is the rule of threes. Intro, body, conclusion. Each paragraph, each idea, each paper will have (1) an introduction, (2)a body to introduce evidence, (3)and a conclusion that draws the body together to support the conclusion. Each paragraph's end should not only neatly conclude that paragraph, but also smoothly transition to the introduction of the next paragraph. It's useful to use an outline form to roughly sketch out your paper. This is a link to one of many sites that will give a longer more thorough explanation : Purdue OWL: Essay Writing It's important to know your subject matter. When you do your paper outline, you will not only organize your paper, you may also find that there are gaps in your grasp of the subject matter. Then do the research to fill those gaps. If you don't, it will show in the final presentation as an unevenly written paper : some solid writing interspersed with thinly supported writing. The reader will not come away confident that you made a solid argument. Write several rough drafts. Don't be too specific and lengthy in details. It will be mostly garbage. You just want to get a feel of the general shape of your paper, to see if you're in the right place or need to redirect. Then, when you are confident in your outline and rough drafts, begin to write your argument.
